{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Enigmata | image = Enigma film.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Michael Apted]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Mick Jagger]]|[[Lorne Michaels]]}} | screenplay = [[Tom Stoppard]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Enigma (novel)|Enigma]]''|[[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Dougray Scott]]|[[Kate Winslet]]|[[Jeremy Northam]]|[[Saffron Burrows]]|[[Tom Hollander]]}} | music = [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]] | cinematography = [[Seamus McGarvey]] | editing = Rick Shaine | studio = {{ubl|Jagged Films|[[Broadway Video]]}} | distributor = {{ubl|[[Buena Vista International|BVI]] (UK)|Manhattan Pictures (US)}} | released = {{Film date|df=y|2001|01|22|[[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2001|08|18|[[Edinburgh Film Festival|Edinburgh]]|2001|09|28|UK|2002|04|19|US}} | runtime = 119 min. | country = {{ubl|United Kingdom|United States}} | language = English | budget = | gross = $15,705,007 (Worldwide)<ref>{{cite web | title=Enigma at Box Office Mojo | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=enigma02.htm | accessdate=2010-09-29}}</ref> }} '''''Enigma''''' is a 2001 [[Spy film|espionage thriller]] film directed by [[Michael Apted]] from a screenplay by [[Tom Stoppard]]. The script was adapted from the novel ''[[Enigma (novel)|Enigma]]'' by [[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]], about the [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] codebreakers of [[Bletchley Park]] in the [[Second World War]].
Although the story is highly fictionalised, the process of encrypting German messages during World War II and decrypting them with the Enigma is discussed in detail, and the historical event of the [[Katyn massacre]] is highlighted. It was the last film scored by [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]].
==Plot== The story, loosely based on actual events, takes place in March 1943, when the [[Second World War]] was at its height. The [[cryptanalysis|cryptanalysts]] at [[Bletchley Park]], [[Buckinghamshire]], have a problem: the [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]] [[U-boat]]s have changed one of their code reference books used for [[Enigma machine]] [[cipher]]s, leading to a blackout in the flow of vital naval [[signals intelligence]]. The British cryptanalysts have cracked the [[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma#M4 (German Navy 4-rotor Enigma)|"Shark" cipher]] once before, and they need to do it again in order to keep track of U-boat locations.
The film begins with Tom Jericho returning to Bletchley after a month recovering from a nervous breakdown brought on by his failed love affair with a coworker named Claire Romilly. Jericho immediately seeks to see her again and finds that she mysteriously disappeared a few days earlier. He enlists the help of Claire's housemate, Hester Wallace, to follow the trail of clues and learn what has happened to Claire.
Mr. Jericho and Miss Wallace, as they formally address each other, work to decipher intercepts stolen by Claire and determine why she took them. Jericho is closely watched by an [[MI5]] agent, Wigram ([[Jeremy Northam]]), who plays [[cat and mouse]] with him throughout the film. Meanwhile, U-boats are closing in on a convoy of thirty seven ships from America, giving the code-breakers less than four days to find a solution to reading the changed Shark cipher.
But someone else at Bletchley has a personal interest in the stolen intercepts, and may be responsible for Claire's disappearance.
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Dougray Scott]] as Tom Jericho * [[Kate Winslet]] as Hester Wallace * [[Saffron Burrows]] as Claire Romilly * [[Jeremy Northam]] as Mr Wigram * [[Nikolaj Coster-Waldau]] as Jozef 'Puck' Pukowski * [[Tom Hollander]] as Guy Logie * [[Donald Sumpter]] as Leveret * [[Matthew Macfadyen]] as Cave * [[Robert Pugh]] as Skynner * [[Corin Redgrave]] as Admiral Trowbridge * [[Nicholas Rowe (actor)|Nicholas Rowe]] as Villiers * [[Edward Hardwicke]] as Heaviside {{div col end}}
==Production and premiere== [[File:BletcleyPark SubModel.JPG|thumb|The scaled-down model of a Second World War U-boat used in the film. The model was donated to the [[Bletchley Park]] museum.]] The film was shot on location in [[England]], [[Scotland]] and the [[Netherlands]], with Bletchley Park mansion substituted by [[Chicheley Hall]].<ref>Sleeve notes from DVD.</ref> Other locations include the [[Great Central Railway]], [[Loughborough]] and Tigh Beg Croft, near [[Oban]], Scotland. Interiors were filmed at [[Elstree Film Studios]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0157583/locations IMDb: ''Locations for Enigma''] Retrieved 2013-04-01</ref>
The film was produced by [[Mick Jagger]] of [[the Rolling Stones]]. Jagger makes a cameo appearance as an RAF officer at a dance. He also lent the film's design department a four-rotor Enigma encoding machine he owned to ensure the historical accuracy of one of the props. The festivities around the London premiere of the film are shown in the 2001 documentary ''[[Being Mick]]''.
==Reception== [[File:Sunbeam Talbot 2 litre Sports Tourer 1947.jpg|thumb|The Sunbeam-Talbot 2-litre driven by the character Tom Jericho in the film]] Critical reviews were largely positive, but there was criticism of the largely fictional storyline, which neither mentions the real codebreaker, [[Alan Turing]], nor gives due credit to the Polish cryptanalysis foundation, the [[Biuro Szyfrów]] (Cipher Bureau). The film holds a 'fresh' 72% rating on review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with the consensus reading, 'The well-crafted, twist-filled Enigma is a thinking person's spy thriller.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1113649-enigma/|title=Enigma|date=19 April 2002|website=Rottentomatoes.com|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> Joe Leydon of [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] compared the film to works by [[Alfred Hitchcock]], and remarked that, 'Overall, "Enigma" plays fair and square while generating suspense with its twisty plot. And while it requires a generous suspension of disbelief to accept a few action-hero gestures by the deeply troubled Jericho, Scott is persuasive and compelling enough as his complex character to drive the narrative.'<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/film/markets-festivals/enigma-2-1200466247/|title=Review: ‘Enigma’|first=Joe|last=Leydon|date=24 January 2001|website=Variety.com|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film three stars and said, 'What I like about the movie is its combination of suspense and intelligence. If it does not quite explain exactly how decryption works (how could it?), it at least gives us a good idea of how decrypters work, and we understand how crucial Bletchley was—so crucial its existence was kept a secret for 30 years.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/enigma-2002|title=Enigma Movie Review & Film Summary (2002) - Roger Ebert|first=Roger|last=Ebert|website=Rogerebert.com|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> On the other end, [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' was far less impressed, saying, 'The legend of how the British cracked the almighty Enigma must have sounded, on paper, like a nifty mathematical thriller—a historic WarGames set at the formative moment of the computer age. On screen, however, Enigma plays as if the scriptwriter, Tom Stoppard, and the director, Michael Apted, were themselves cryptographers; they seem to be making hunt-and-peck stabs at how to translate a tale of arcane numeric formulas into drama.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2002/05/03/enigma|title=Enigma |website=Ew.com|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
==Historical accuracy== The film and, by association, the book have attracted criticism for their portrayal of the Polish role in [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] [[decryption]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmweb.pl/Norman%20Davies%20oskar%C5%BCa%20%22Enigm%C4%99%22,News,id=3946|title=Norman Davies oskarża "Enigmę"|website=Filmweb.pl|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> The historian [[Norman Davies]] argues that in the film the fictitious traitor turns out to be Polish, but only slight mention is made of the contributions of prewar Polish [[Biuro Szyfrów|Cipher Bureau]] [[cryptologist]]s to [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] Enigma decryption efforts,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8158782.stm|title=How Poles cracked Nazi Enigma secret|author=Peter, Laurence | publisher= [[BBC News]]|accessdate=20 July 2009}}</ref> but historically, the only known traitor active at Bletchley Park was British spy [[John Cairncross]], who passed crucial secrets to the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1999/09/99/britain_betrayed/444058.stm | title=Britain betrayed: The Cambridge spy ring | publisher=BBC News | date=September 13, 1999 | accessdate=December 25, 2017}}</ref>
The film hints that [[Dougray Scott]]’s character the brilliant Cambridge mathematician Thomas Jericho is the main code-breaker at [[Bletchley Park|Bletchley]], equating him with [[Alan Turing]], the original creator of the British [[Bombe]], with the words of Mr Wigram, played by [[Jeremy Northam]]: “But what if someone tells them just how we do do it? Your thinking machine, clackity-clack, day and night, programmed with a menu, thanks to your big brain, that reduces the odds to just a few million-to-one until it locks on to the winning combination. There goes the war…” Of course Jericho is a totally fictional character, given that Turing was homosexual and only had a platonic relationship with his short-lived fiancé [[Joan Clarke]], who knew about his sexual orientation. In reality it was unlikely that Turing was involved in code-breaking the Naval four-rotor Enigma Shark in 1943. Notes by [[Tony Sale]] do not mention Turing as the “someone in Bletchley Park [who] realised that Short Weather Signals were sent in the three wheel mode” and explained “the Central Met. Station had collated the U-Boat and other reports, [and] they broadcast a general synoptic in their own Met. Code”, which used the standard International Met. Code further encoded using bigram tables, as discovered by Mr Archer from the Met. section of Bletchley Park.<ref>[http://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/virtualbp/navenigma/navenig9.htm ''Breaking Shark on the Short Weather Signals'' - The Breaking of German Naval Enigma by Tony Sale] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref> According to [[Conel Hugh O'Donel Alexander|Hugh Alexander]], from June 1943 Joan Clarke, Mahon, Pendered and Noskwith, were responsible for the whole of the cryptographic work until the end of the war.<ref>[http://www.turing.org.uk/book/update/part5.html ''Update to Alan Turing: the Enigma by Andrew Hodges Part 5: Running Up'', Turing.org] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref> Strangely Joan Clarke is not present in the film as none of the team of [[cryptanalysis|cryptanalysts]] are female.
In the film Cave, from Naval Intelligence, played by [[Matthew Macfadyen]], mentioned Fasson and Grazier gave their lives to rescue the code books from a sinking submarine. There were actually three men who retrieved the books: [[Tony Fasson|First Lieutenant Anthony Fasson]], [[Colin Grazier|Able Seaman Colin Grazier]] and 16-year old [[Tommy Brown (NAAFI assistant)|Tommy Brown]] from the canteen. Fasson and Grazier did drown while attempting to retrieve electrical equipment from U Boat [[German submarine U-559|U-559]] (which Cave describes as its four-rotor enigma) on 30 October 1942, while Brown survived only to die in a house fire during shore-leave before the end of the war.<ref>[http://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/virtualbp/navenigma/navenig8.htm ''The Documents recovered from U559 - at a price'', The Breaking of German Naval Enigma by Tony Sale] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/20/enigma-code-u-boat-u559-hms-petard-sebag-montefiori ''The boarding of U-559 changed the war – now both sides tell their story'', The Guardian, 21 Oct 2017] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/teen-who-rescued-enigma-codes-9707940 ''Teen who rescued Enigma codes from sinking sub died in house fire without knowing the significance of his bravery'', The Mirror, 27 Jan 2017] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref> Fasson and Grazier were awarded the [[George Cross]] posthumously and Brown was awarded the [[George Medal]].<ref name=NAVAL_ENIGMA>[https://uboat.net/technical/enigma_breaking.htm ''Allied Breaking of Naval Enigma'', uboat.net] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref> Fictional character Cave states he was completing his last posting on a destroyer, in November ’42, when the books were acquired.
There are historical records of the break in the ability of the British to decode the Naval enigma from 10 to 19 March 1943 when the third edition of the weather short signal codebook was deployed<ref name=NAVAL_ENIGMA />.
The [[Katyn massacre]], revealed after the discovery of mass graves of 4,500 Polish officers as depicted in the film, is a historical atrocity committed by Stalinist Russia in 1940. There is no evidence that details of the mass graves were intercepted by British intelligence, although it is possible. The first announcement of the discovery was broadcast by Radio Berlin on 13 April 1943.<ref>[http://www.historylearningsite.co.uk/world-war-two/world-war-two-and-eastern-europe/the-katyn-wood-massacre/ ''The Katyn Wood Massacre'', C N Trueman, The History Learning Site, 18 May 2015] Retrieved 25 Nov 2017</ref>
==See also== * ''[[The Imitation Game]]'' - A 2014 biopic of Alan Turing and his involvement in cracking the Enigma. * ''[[U-571 (film)|U-571]]'' - A 2000 war film involving the capture of an Enigma machine. * [[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma]] * [[Ultra]]
==References== <references />
==External links== {{commons category}} * {{IMDb title|0157583|Enigma}} * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1113649-enigma/ ''Enigma''] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] * [http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=enigma02.htm ''Enigma''] at [[Box Office Mojo]] * [http://www.cryptographic.co.uk/enigmareview.html Review by Andrew Hodges]
{{Michael Apted}} {{Tom Stoppard}} {{Lorne Michaels}}

'''''For the Liberation of Brazil''''' is a [[Marxist]] tract on [[guerrilla warfare]] written by [[Carlos Marighella]]. First published in France as ''Carlos Marighela: Pour la Libération du Brésil'' presented by [[Conrad Detrez]], [[Editions du Seuil]], 1970. In March 1970 the ''[[Journal officiel de la République française|Journal Official]]'' announced that the sale and distribution of the book throughout French territory would be forbidden.
It was then published in English by [[Penguin Books]] in 1971 as part of their "[[Pelican Latin American Library]]" series and with more material than the French version. This edition was translated by [[John Butt (translator)|John Butt]] and [[Rosemary Sheed]] with an introduction by [[Richard Gott]] (pp. 7-15).
The first part of the book provides a timeline of events that includes actions taken by the [[Revolutionary Movement 8th October]].
# "Marighela Calls on the People to Join the Struggle" (Sept 1969) # "Declaration by the [[Ação Libertadora Nacional|ALN October Revolutionary Group]]" (Sept 1969) # "Greetings to the Fifteen Patriots"<ref>These were the 15 exchanged for the kidnapped US ambassador [[Charles Elbrick]]</ref> # "On the Organizational Function of Revolutionary Violence" (May 1969) # "Problems and Principles of Strategy" (Jan 1969) # "Questions of Organization" (Dec 1968) # "Handbook of Urban Guerrilla Warfare" (June 1969) # "On Rural Guerrilla Warfare"<ref>Originally broadcast from a captured radio station in 1969</ref> # "Guerrilla Tactics and Operations" # "Call to the Brazilian People " # "Letter to [[Fidel Castro]]" (Aug 1967) # "Declaration by the Communist Group of [[São Paulo]]"
The second part consists of articles written in 1966 before he left the [[Brazilian Communist Party]] including his resignation letter penned on December 10, 1966.
== Footnotes == {{reflist}}
[[Category:1970 books]] [[Category:Urban guerrilla warfare handbooks and manuals]]
{{mil-book-stub}}

The '''Fortune Global 500''', also known as '''Global 500''', is an annual ranking of the top 500 [[corporation]]s worldwide as measured by [[revenue]] and the list is compiled and published annually by ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine. == Methodology == Until 1989, it listed only non-[[United States]] industrial corporations under the title "International 500" while the [[Fortune 500]] contained and still contains exclusively United States corporations. In 1990, United States companies were added to compile a truly global list of top industrial corporations as ranked by sales. Since 1995, the list has had its current form, listing also top financial corporations and service providers by revenue. === Controversy === Several inconsistencies exist in Fortune's ranking of cities with the most Fortune 500 headquarters. On June 3, 2011, the ''[[Atlanta Business Chronicle]]'' stated examples of ''Fortune'' including regional headquarters for some cities, not including regional headquarters for other cities and in some cases not including headquarters that are physically located inside a city limit.{{cite web|title=Some cities rankings are overstated|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2011/06/03/fortune-500-list-overstates-atlantas.html|author=Maria Saporta|publisher=Atlanta Business Chronicle|accessdate=28 October 2012}} == Geographical distribution == Since 2001, there has been a significant change in the geographical distribution of the companies in the Global 500 rankings. The number of [[North America]]n-based companies decreased from 215 in 2001 to 143 in 2017{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} and the contribution of [[Asia]]n-based companies increased rapidly from 116 in 2001 to 197 in 2017{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}. Most of this growth is accounted for by the rapid increase in the number of Chinese Global 500 companies, of which there were 109 by 2017, increasing from only 10 in 2001. The share of [[Europe]]an-based companies also reduced, from 158 to 143, over the same period.{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/global500/|title=A New Perspective on the Corporate World|accessdate=8 July 2013|publisher=CNN Money, Fortune Magazine}}{{cite web|url=http://beta.fortune.com/global500/visualizations/?iid=recirc_g500landing-zone1|title=Visualize The Global 500|website=Fortune}}[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/40-of-fortune-500-companies-asian-india-has-7-in-list/articleshow/59707630.cms Fortune 500 companies list: 40% of Fortune 500 companies Asian, India has 7 in list - Times of India] == Fortune Global 500 list of year 2018 == The following is the list of top 10 companies.{{Cite {{use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox book | name = Friendly Fascism:
The New Face of Power in America | translator = | image = FriendlyFascism-FirstEdition-BookCover.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Bertram Gross]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | publisher = M. Evans & Company | release_date = June 1, 1980 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 419 | isbn = 0871313170 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Friendly Fascism: The New Face of Power in America''''' is a [[book]] written by American [[social scientist]] and professor of [[political science]] at [[Hunter College]] [[Bertram Myron Gross|Bertram Gross]] and published on June 1, 1980 by M. Evans & Company as a 419-page hardback book containing 440 quotations and sources. The book examines the history of [[fascism]] and based on the growth of [[big business]] and [[big government]] describes [[Scenario planning|possible political scenarios]] for a [[Futures studies|future United States]]. According to a 1981 review in the journal [[Social Justice (journal)|''Social Justice'']], the book is described as "timely" on a subject requiring serious consideration and is about the dangers of fascism, focusing primarily on the United States, but being aware that [[monopoly capitalism]] needs to be understood internationally since [[capitalism]] "is not a national [[mode of production]]". In 2016, the book prompted the following response right after [[Donald Trump]] was elected [[President of the United States]]: "The next wave of fascists will not come with [[Stock car (rail)|cattle cars]] and [[Internment|concentration camps]], but they'll come with a [[Smiley|smiley face]] and maybe a [[Television show|TV show]]. [...] That’s how the 21st-century fascists will essentially take over". == Reactions == According to [[Jason Epstein]], editor, publisher and book reviewer for ''[[The New York Review of Books]]'', "''Friendly Fascism'' [...] reflects what seems to be a widespread feeling among [[Liberalism in the United States|liberals]] as well as [[Conservatism in the United States|conservatives]] that [[democracy]] in America has played itself out: that soon Americans won’t be able to govern themselves".{{cite news |last=Epstein |first=Jason |authorlink=Jason Epstein |title=Is the Party Over? |url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/1980/10/23/is-the-party-over/ |date=October 23, 1980 |work=[[The New York Review of Books]] |accessdate=September 19, 2018 }} According to [[Gaddis Smith]], professor emeritus of history at [[Yale University]] and an expert on American [[International relations|foreign relations]], the book is an "insightful lament over the growth of centralized power by business and government in alliance under the direction of faceless managers who [...] are replacing democracy with a form of benevolent fascism".{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Gaddis |authorlink=Gaddis Smith |title=Friendly Fascism: The New Face of Power in America (capsule review) |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/1980-09-01/friendly-fascism-new-face-power-america |date=September 1, 1980 |work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |accessdate=September 19, 2018 }} Writing on behalf of ''[[Eclectica Magazine]]'', reviewer Dale Wharton comments that the book offers "faint hope of averting [[neofascism]]", but as a possible offset suggests raising aspirations, notably by "setting forth clear lofty goals, broad enough to embrace a great majority". Help may come from insiders since "bubbling upward from all levels of the [[The Establishment|Establishment]] are longings for fulfilling [[employment]] disconnected from [[Consumerism|consumer exploitation]], [[environmental degradation]], or [[militarism]]".{{cite web |last=Wharton |first=Dale |title=A review by Dale Wharton: Frienndly Fascism: The New Face of Power in America by Bertram Gross |url=http://www.eclectica.org/v1n1/reviews/wharton_friendly.html |date= |work=[[Eclectica Magazine]] |accessdate=September 20, 2018 }} Reviewer Dennis Phillips notes in the ''Australian Journal of Law & Society'' that Gross wrote ''Friendly Fascism'' before [[Ronald Reagan]] had become [[President of the United States]], but Reagan's United States, presumed in part to be a result of neofascist techniques described in the book, had "proven Bertram Gross to be an amazingly astute prophet . [...] The evidence for this [in the book] is stunning".{{cite journal |last=Phillips |first=Dennis |title=Book Review: Friendly Fascism: The new face of power in America by Bertram Gross |url=http://classic.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/AUJlLawSoc/1982/11.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=1982 |journal=Australian Journal of Law & Society |volume=1 |number=1 |pages=136-140 |accessdate=September 20, 2018 }} According to a book review in the journal [[Social Justice (journal)|''Social Justice'']] by Gregory Shank of the Institute for the Study of Labor and Economic Crisis, "''Friendly Fascism'' [...] is written to alert readers to a clear and present danger in the current trajectory of [[American politics]]".{{cite journal |last=Shank |first=Gregory |title=Book Review: 'Friendly Fascism: The New Face of Power in America' by Bertram Gross |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/29766120?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents |date=1981 |work=[[Social Justice (journal)|Social Justice]] |volume=15 |pages=71-79 |accessdate=September 19, 2018 }} More recently in 2016, the book prompted the following response from [[Michael Moore]] right after [[Donald Trump]] was elected President: "The next wave of fascists will not come with [[Stock car (rail)|cattle cars]] and [[Internment|concentration camps]], but they'll come with a [[Smiley|smiley face]] and maybe a [[Television show|TV show]]. [...] That’s how the 21st-century fascists will essentially take over".{{cite news |last=Jacobs |first=Matthew |authorlink=Matthew Jacobs |title=Michael Moore: Fascists Now Come With ‘A Smiley Face And Maybe A TV Show’ |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/michael-moore-donald-trump_us_5829c5bce4b02d21bbc97cab |date=November 14, 2016 |work=[[HuffPost]] |accessdate=September 19, 2018 }} == Related history == Fascism has been perceived to be a last resort weapon of the privileged to ensure the maintenance of [[wage slavery]]: {{cquote|No government fights fascism to destroy it. When the [[bourgeoisie]] sees that power is slipping out of its hands, it brings up fascism to hold onto their privileges.|author=[[Buenaventura Durruti]]|source=quote from an interview with [[Pierre van Paassen]], July 24, 1936{{cite web |last=Durruti |first=Buenaventura |authorlink=Buenaventura Durruti |title=Quote from an interview with Pierre van Paassen (July 24, 1936) |url=https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Buenaventura_Durruti#Van_Paassen_interview_(1936) |date=August 5, 1936 |work=[[Toronto Daily Star]] |accessdate=September 19, 2018}}}} == See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Anti-fascism]] * [[Manifesto of the Anti-Fascist Intellectuals]] * ''[[The Power Elite]]'', 1956 book * [[Power (social and political)]] * [[Presidency of Donald Trump]] * "[[The Waldo Moment#Reception|The Waldo Moment]]", 2016 TV episode {{div col end}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * C. W Mills (1958). [http://www.csub.edu/~akebede/SOC502Mills2.pdf "The Structure of Power in American Society"] (PDF). ''British Journal of Socoiology''. Vol. 9. No. 1. * [http://www.worldfuturefund.org/wffmaster/Reading/Germany/mussolini.htm "The Doctrine of Fascism"]. Complete text of the essay "Dottrina" ("Doctrines"). A translation of the Benito Mussolini "Doctrines" section of the "Fascism" entry in the 1932 edition of the ''[[Enciclopedia Italiana]]''. From the publication ''Fascism: Doctrine and Institutions'' (1935) by [[Benito Mussolini]], Ardita Publishers, Rome. Footnote numbers inserted in the text and a footnote appendix (both not found in the 1932 encyclopedia article) are found in this 1935 publication. The footnotes contain excerpts from his speeches. * [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/mod/mussolini-fascism.html "Benito Mussolini: What is Fascism?"]. * [https://www.nytimes.com/video/opinion/100000006154922/fascism-leaders-america-trump.html Video (05:02) - Fascism in the USA?] ([[The New York Times]]; October 15, 2018) {{Fascism}} {{portal bar|Business|Government|Politics|United States}} [[Category:1980 books]] [[Category:Anti-fascism]] [[Category:Books about fascism]] [[Category:Political concepts]] [[Category:Political movements]] [[Category:Power (social and political)| ]] [[Category:Social concepts]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Taiwanese music organisations to [[:Category:Music organisations based in Taiwan]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 9]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Rose Tachung Records
玫瑰大眾唱片 | logo = [[Image:玫瑰大眾-logo.gif|center|300px]]
G-Music Limited (Chinese 重聚典企業股份有限公司 "Chóngjùdiǎn Enterprises Limited")
Rose Records 玫瑰唱片 méiguī chàngpiàn(pink logo) and Tachung Records 大众唱片 Dàzhòng chàngpiàn (blue logo) | products = Audio-visual| industry = [[Sound recording and reproduction|records]], [[retail]] | location = [[Taiwan]], [[Zhongzheng District]], South Chongqing Road 1-duan 15, 9F| type = Music retailer| website = [http://www.g-music.com.tw Company website (Chinese)] }} '''G-Music Limited''' is a company built in 2002 by '''Rose Records''' and '''Tachung Records''',{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=24114139|title=Company Overview of G-Music Limited|work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate=March 24, 2014}} both are the largest local music retails and wholesale chains in Taiwan. The physical retail arms have been kept separate, for different customer bases and brand identity, but the e-retailing, wholesale and distributor business is unified as '''Rose Tachung Records'''. The two chains originally teamed up to create Taiwan's popular music ranking, the '''G-Music Chart''' (Chinese: 風雲榜 ''fēngyúnbǎng'').{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wZrbAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT166#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Global Music Industry: Three Perspectives|first=Arthur|last=Bernstein|first2=Naoki|last2=Sekine|first3=Dick|last3=Weissman|year=2013|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=9781135922474}}{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iKolvnUOHegC&pg=PA146&lpg=PA146&dq=G-Music+Taiwan&source=bl&ots=0kof26Z51v&sig=8loH4zNbOIC8c7YUjzSk9fSQaRY&hl=id&sa=X&ei=y_0vU9XxDKPQiAfPo4HwCg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=G-Music%20Taiwan&f=false|title=Cries of Joy, Songs of Sorrow: Chinese Pop Music and Its Cultural Connotations|first=Marc L.|last=Moskowitz|year=2010|publisher=[[University of Hawaii Press]]|isbn=9780824833695}} The chains had around 60 locations in 2002.Billboard Tachung's network includes Taiwan's only remaining specialist classical CD store, opposite the [[Taipei YMCA]] on Hsu Chang St.Tachung Records Classical Store, 大眾唱片行(許昌店), 台北市許昌街24號, (02)2389-3611. G-Music Chart remains the most popular record chart in Taiwan.{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TBgPIHbgaIUC&pg=PA138&lpg=PA138&dq=G-Music+Taiwan&source=bl&ots=HiFilutaWi&sig=tq9mVBpHBlDJo_ELqcuPgZ5WBSU&hl=id&sa=X&ei=8P0vU7iLAsaPiAf4vIDYDg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=G-Music%20Taiwan&f=false|title=Globalization and the Regional Flow of Popular Music: The Role of the Korean Wave (Hanliu) in the Construction of Taiwanese Identities and Asian Values|year=2008|first=Sang-Yeon|last=Sung|publisher=[[Indiana University]]. [[ProQuest]]|isbn=9780549703242}}{{cite news|url=http://english.kbs.co.kr/hallyu/entertainment_news_view.html?No=8333|title=FT Island’s 4th Album Hits #1 on Taiwan’s Weekly Music Chart|date=October 16, 2012|publisher=[[Korean Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=March 24, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/biz/archives/2012/06/24/2003536091|title=Asian stars go overseas to find fame|first=Amber|last=Wang|work=[[Taipei Times]]|date=June 24, 2012|accessdate=March 24, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://stcommunities.straitstimes.com/music/2013/03/06/taiwan-indie-label-bin-music-goes-back-basics-good-material-live-shows|title=Taiwan indie label B'in Music goes back to basics: good material, live shows|work=[[The Straits Times]]|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]|date=March 6, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2014}} ==G-Music Chart== The G-Music Chart was first officially published on July 7, 2005, and compiled the top physically sold CD releases in Taiwan (including both albums and physically released singles). Only the top 20 positions are published, and instead of sales, a percentage ranking is listed next to each release. For example, in the 52nd week of 2006, ''[[Born to Love (Mayday album)|Born to Love]]'', ranked at number one, sold 25.46% of the CDs sold in Taiwan that week. G-Music's main chart, '''Combo Chart''' (Chinese: 綜合榜 ''zònghé bǎng''), ranks all music sales, regardless of language, country of origin or genre. ===Sub charts=== In addition to the main chart, there are eight sub-charts, and one defunct chart. All charts feature a percentage ranking, which is the percentage sold for each subcategory. All charts began on the same day as the Combo Chart, July 7, 2005. The currently operating sub-charts are: *''Mandarin Chart'' (Chinese: 華語榜 ''Huáyǔ bǎng'') ranks releases in Chinese language. *''Western Chart'' (Chinese: 西洋榜 ''Xīyáng bǎng'') ranks predominantly English releases from [[North America]], [[Europe]] or other Western countries. *''J-Pop Chart'' (Chinese: 東洋榜 ''Dōngyáng bǎng'', "East Asian Chart") ranks non-Chinese Asian language albums. Originally named for [[Japanese language|Japanese]] releases, the chart increasingly features musicians singing in [[Korean language|Korean]]. *''Jazz Chart'' (Chinese: 爵士榜 ''Juéshì bǎng'') ranks [[jazz]] releases, regardless of nationality or language. *''Classical Chart'' (Chinese: 古典榜 ''Gǔdiǎn bǎng'') ranks classical music releases, regardless of nationality or language. *''Audio/Video Chart'' (Chinese: 影音榜 ''Yǐngyīn bǎng'') ranks music-related DVD and Blu-ray releases, regardless of nationality, language or genre. *''International Chart'' (Chinese: 外語榜 ''Wàiyǔ bǎng'') combines the Western Chart and J-Pop Chart together In addition to these, a Taiwanese singles chart called the ''Top Chinese Chart'' (Chinese: 百事榜 ''Bǎishì bǎng'', "[[Pepsi]] Chart"), also called the "[[Mengniu Dairy]] Chart" (蒙牛榜 ''Méngniú bǎng''), was created at the start of 2006. It ranked the top songs in two different top 20 charts: one for [[Mainland China]] (内地榜單 ''Nèidì bǎngdān'') and one combining [[Hong Kong]] and Taiwan (港臺榜單 ''Gǎng-tái bǎngdān''). The chart was made defunct in September 2008. ==References== {{reflist|40em}} ==External links== *[http://www.g-music.com.tw/ g-music.com.tw, combined site of Rose Tachung Records] {{Record Charts}} {{Music industry}} [[Category:Music retailers]] [[Category:Online music stores]] [[Category:Record charts]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Taiwan]] [[Category:Music organisations based in Taiwan]]

revision.text:
In the field of [[IPv6 deployment]], '''IPv6 brokenness''' was bad behavior seen in early [[IPv6#Dual IP stack implementation#Tunneling|tunneled]] or [[IPv6#Dual IP stack implementation|dual stack]] [[IPv6]] deployments where unreliable or bogus IPv6 connectivity is chosen in preference to working IPv4 connectivity. This often resulted in long delays in [[web page]] loading, where the user had to wait for each attempted IPv6 connection to [[timeout (computing)|time out]] before the IPv4 connection was tried.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/20101012_ipv6_and_the_fear_of_brokenness/|title=IPv6 and the Fear of Brokenness|author=Yves Poppe|publisher=CircleID|date=Oct 12, 2010|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref> These timeouts ranged from being near-instantaneous in the best cases, to taking anywhere between four seconds to three minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nanog.org/meetings/nanog50/presentations/Wednesday/NANOG50.Talk41.colitti-IPv6%20transition%20experiences.pdf|title=IPv6 transition experiences|author=Lorenzo Colitti, Google|accessdate=2010-12-29}} presented at NANOG 50</ref>
IPv6 brokenness is now generally regarded as a solved problem for almost all practical purposes, following improvements at both the transport and application layers.<ref name=":0" />
== Brokenness ==
As of May 2011, IPv6 brokenness as measured by instrumenting a set of mainstream Norwegian websites was down to ~0.015%,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fud.no/ipv6/|title=IPv6 dual-stack client loss in Norway|author=Tore Anderson|accessdate=2011-06-16}}</ref> most of which was caused by older versions of [[Mac OS X]] which would often prefer non-working IPv6 connectivity when it was not justified.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ripe61.ripe.net/presentations/162-ripe61.pdf|title=Measuring and combating IPv6 brokenness|author=Tore Anderson|accessdate=2010-12-29}}, presented at RIPE 61, Rome, November 2010</ref> This behavior was fixed in Mac OS X 10.6.5, and is likely to decline further as Mac OS X 10.6.5 and subsequent versions roll out to a wider audience. However, there was no upgrade path for [[PowerPC]]-based Macs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2010/11/apple-fixes-broken-ipv6-by-breaking-it-some-more.ars|title=Apple fixes broken IPv6 by breaking it some more|publisher=Ars Technica|author=Iljitsch van Beijnum|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref>
The main remaining problem for Mac OS X was the presence of rogue routers, such as wrongly configured Windows [[Internet Connection Sharing]] devices pretending to have IPv6 connectivity, while 6to4 tunneled IPv6 traffic is blocked at a firewall.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} Another problem was pre-10.50 versions of Opera.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}}
Following [[World IPv6 Day]] in July 2011, there were reports of a substantial reduction in IPv6 brokenness as a result of that experiment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkworld.com/news/2011/072711-ipv6-brokenness.html|title='IPv6 brokenness' problem appears fixed|author=Carolyn Duffy Marsan|publisher=Network World|date=July 27, 2011}}</ref> In the year following the trial, but prior to the [[World IPv6 Launch]] date, brokenness levels were reported to have risen slowly back upwards again towards 0.03%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1001_3-57445316-92/internet-powers-flip-the-ipv6-switch-faq/?tag=postrtcol;posts|title=Internet powers flip the IPv6 switch (FAQ)|author=Stephen Shankland|date=June 4, 2012|publisher=CNET News}}</ref>
== DNS whitelisting == [[Google]], a major provider of services on the Internet, experimented with using a type of '''DNS whitelisting''' on a per-ISP basis to prevent this<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/intl/en/ipv6/|title=Google over IPv6|publisher=Google|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/web/news/2010/03/yahoo-wants-two-faced-dns-to-aid-ipv6-deployment.ars|title=Yahoo wants two-faced DNS to aid IPv6 deployment|author=Iljitsch van Beijnum|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref> until the World IPv6 Launch. In the DNS whitelisting approach, ISPs are determined from [[DNS lookup]] source IP addresses by correlating them with network prefixes derived from [[routing table]]s. There is an [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-livingood-dns-whitelisting-implications IETF draft] entitled "IPv6 AAAA DNS Whitelisting Implications" that describes the issues around whitelisting. AAAA records are only sent to ISPs that can demonstrate that they are providing reliable IPv6 to their customers. Other ISPs are sent only A records, thus preventing users from attempting to connect over IPv6.
Numerous concerns were been raised about the practicality of DNS whitelisting as a long-term large-scale solution, such as scalability and maintenance issues relating to the maintenance of large numbers of bilateral agreements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/79/slides/dnsop-1.pdf|title=IPv6 DNS Whitelisting — Overview and Implications|author=Jason Livingood|date=October 2010|publisher=Comcast|accessdate=2010-12-29}}, presented at IETF79, Beijing</ref> In 2010, several of the major web service providers met to discuss pooling their DNS whitelisting information in an attempt to avoid these scaling problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.techworld.com/networking/3218712/google-microsoft-and-yahoo-talk-about-ipv6-whitelist/|title=Google, Microsoft and Yahoo talk about IPv6 whitelist|publisher=Techworld|date=29 March 2010|author=Carolyn Duffy Marsan|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref>
== Problem resolution == It appears that no major content providers eventually ended up using the whitelisting approach, given that all that had previously declared an interest began serving AAAA records to generic DNS queries following [[World IPv6 Launch Day]]. Google now provides AAAA records to all DNS servers except for those on a limited list of subnets which Google excludes from AAAA record service.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://googleblog.blogspot.co.uk/2012/06/world-ipv6-launch-keeping-internet.html|title=World IPv6 Launch: Keeping the Internet growing|newspaper=Official Google Blog|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/intl/en_ALL/ipv6/statistics/data/no_aaaa.txt|title=Google IPv6 AAAA record network exclusion list|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Google|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref>
As of 2017, IPv6 brokenness is now generally regarded as a non-problem. This is due to two factors: firstly, IPv6 transport is much improved, so that the underlying error rate is much reduced, and secondly, that common applications such as web browsers now use fast fallback methods such as the "[[Happy Eyeballs]]" algorithm to select whichever protocol works best.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2179639/lan-wan/-ipv6-brokenness--problem-appears-fixed.html|title='IPv6 brokenness' problem appears fixed|last=Marsan|first=Carolyn Duffy|newspaper=Network World|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref> Some operating system vendors have rolled fast fallback algorithms into their higher-level [[Protocol stack|network stack]] APIs, thus making the solution available for all programs that use those APIs to make connections.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/08/world-ipv6-day-leads-to-browsers-resistant-to-ipv6-brokenness/|title=In wake of World IPv6 Day, browsers resist IPv6 brokenness—but should they?|newspaper=Ars Technica|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref>
== See also == * [[World IPv6 Day and World IPv6 Launch Day]] * [[IPv6 deployment]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{cite web|url=http://vyncke.org/testv6/|title=Estimation of IPv6 Brokenness|author=Eric Vyncke|date=October 2010|accessdate=2010-12-29}} — continuously updated * {{cite web|url=http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-v6ops-v6-aaaa-whitelisting-implications|title=IPv6 AAAA DNS Whitelisting Implications|author=J. Livingood|accessdate=2011-01-20}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/features/The-big-IPv6-experiment-1165042.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207044634/http://www.h-online.com/features/The-big-IPv6-experiment-1165042.html|archivedate=7 December 2013|title=The big IPv6 experiment|publisher=h-online.com|date=10 January 2011}}
[[Category:IPv6]] [[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:Technological failures]]

revision.comment: /* Text */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: world famous → world-famous using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Lichtenberg's Avertissement''', written by [[Georg Christoph Lichtenberg]], is a poster intended to deter the citizens of [[Göttingen]], [[Germany]], from attending the performance of [[Jacob Philadelphia]] in 1777.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Publications of the American Jewish Historical Society]]|issue=16 |page=80 |year=1907 |publisher=American Jewish Historical Society}}</ref> The performance was supposed to be an exhibition of scientific experiments; however, Lichtenberg considered it to be a [[magic (illusion)|magic]] show. He was angered by the alleged deception and posted the following [[satire]] in order to persuade people to avoid the performance.<ref>{{cite book | last = Christopher | first = Milbourne | title = Magic, a Picture History | publisher = Dover Publications | location = New York | year = 1991 | isbn = 0-486-26373-8 |page=41}}</ref> As a result of the extravagant claims that were posted, Philadelphia left Göttingen without giving any exhibitions.
==Text== The Avertissement reads as follows:
''Warning''
All fanciers of [[supernatural]] [[physics]] will, by this poster, be made known that a few days ago, the world-famous [[Magician (illusion)|magician]] Philadelphus Philadelphia, who has been mentioned by [[Cardanus]] in his book on the [[nature]] of the supernatural by calling him the envy of [[Heaven]] and [[Hell]], has arrived here on the ordinary mail coach, although it would have been equally easy for him to have come through the air. He is the same person who, in 1482, in an open marketplace in [[Venice]], cast a coil of twine into the air and climbed up until he was no longer seen. Beginning on the ninth of January of this year, he will present, openly and secretly, to the public's eyes, his one-[[Thaler]] tricks in the local department store. The tricks will improve every week until he finally arrives at the 500 [[Louis d'Or]] tricks, among which are those that can be said, without boasting, to surpass the wonderful itself, and be even, so to say, virtually impossible. He had the graciousness to perform these same tricks to great applause before all of the high [[potentate]]s in all four parts of the world. He even performed in the fifth part of the world a few weeks ago for her majesty Queen [[Purea|Oberea]] of [[Tahiti]].
He can be seen here every day, at all hours, except not on Mondays and Thursdays, when he expels melancholy thoughts at the venerable [[Congress]] of his countrymen in Philadelphia. Also, not from 11 a.m. to 12 noon because he is engaged in [[Constantinople]], and not from 12 noon to 1 p.m., when he lunches.
From the one-Thaler, common, everyday tricks, we want to indicate some, but not the best. Rather, we'll refer to those that can be described in a few words.
1) He removes, without leaving the room, the weather cock from the [[St. Jacobi]] church (Göttingen) and sets it on top of the [[St. Johannis (Göttingen)|St. Johannis]] church (Göttingen). On the other hand, he puts the flag from the St. Johannis church on the St. Jacobi church. After they have been there for a few minutes, he brings them back to their proper places. Note: everything is done without [[magnet]]s, through mere speed.
2) He takes two ladies from the audience, positions them with their heads on the table and lets them turn their legs upward. Then, he pushes them so that they, with unbelievable speed, twist themselves like curls, without damage to their head dress or the respectability of the alignment of their dresses, to the greatest satisfaction of all present.
3) He takes six half-[[ounce]]s of the best [[arsenic]], grinds it, and cooks it in two cans of [[milk]]. He then treats it to the ladies. As soon as they become sick, he gives them two or three spoonfuls of melted [[lead]] to drink. The audience then becomes cheerful and breaks out in laughter.
4) He takes an [[axe]] and strikes a [[Bonnet (headgear)|bonnet]] with it. The bonnet falls to the ground as though it is dead. On the ground, he gives it a second blow. The bonnet then rises immediately and asks, in a general way: "What music is that?" In other respects, it is in as good condition as before.
5) He gently extracts [[teeth]] from three or four ladies, puts the teeth in a bag, and lets the audience carefully shake them. Then he loads them into a small [[cannon]] and fires it at the aforementioned ladies. After this, they all have their teeth again, pure and white.
6) A [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] trick. He shows that something actually can be and not be at the same time. This requires great preparation and expense, but he performs it for only one Thaler in honor of the [[University]] of Göttingen.
7) He takes all of the watches, rings, and jewels, as well as gold cash when it is required, from the audience who is present. He then issues everyone an [[IOU (debt)|I.O.U.]]. After this, he throws everything in a suitcase and travels with it to [[Kassel]]. Eight days later, each person tears up their I.O.U.. After it is torn, the watches, rings, and jewelry reappear. He has earned much money with this trick.
Note: This week, he is still in the upper room of the department store. But, in the future, he will be high in the free air over the fountain in the market place. There, whoever pays nothing will see nothing.
Göttingen
January 7, 1777
==Schopenhauer's reference== Philosopher [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] made reference to the sixth trick in his discussion of [[Immanuel Kant|Kant's]] description of the [[antinomy]] (conflict of laws) of pure [[reason]] (''[[Critique of Pure Reason]]'', A406). Schopenhauer wrote: {{Quotation|The unanimous assent which the antinomy, on the other hand, has met with, may in the end spring from the fact that some people regard with inward gratification the point where the understanding is really supposed to be brought to a standstill, since it has hit upon something that at the same time is and is not, and accordingly they actually have here before them the sixth trick of Philadelphia in Lichtenberg's broadsheet.|''[[The World as Will and Representation]]'', Vol. I, Appendix}}
==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} *{{cite book | last = Kant | first = Immanuel | title = Critique of Pure Reason | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | location = Basingstoke | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-0-230-01337-7 }} *{{cite book | last =Schopenhauer | first =Arthur | title = The World as Will and Representation, Volume I | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-0-521-87184-6 }}
==External links== *[http://www.lichtenberg-gesellschaft.de/pdf/l_wirk_satir_anschlag_original.pdf Pdf of the Avertissment]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Louvre-Lens |image =Louvre-Lens-night.jpg |caption = Louvre-Lens, 2015 |pushpin_map = France |coordinates = {{Coord|50.43068889|2.803302778|type:landmark_region:FR-62|format=dms}} |established = {{Start date |2012}} |dissolved = |location = 99 Rue Paul Bert
62300 [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais|Lens]], [[France]] |type = [[Art museum]], Design/Textile Museum, [[Historic site]] |visitors = 700,000 the first year, 450 000 in 2017 |architect = SANAA Kazuyo Sejima & Ryue Nishizawa, Tokyo + Imrey Culbert, New York |director = [[Xavier Dectot]] |curator = Xavier Dectot |publictransit = Bus shuttle from [[gare de Lens]] |website = {{URL|http://www.louvrelens.fr/en/home | Louvre-Lens}} |logo=|latitude=|former_name=}} The '''Louvre-Lens''' is an art museum located in [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais]], [[Northern France]], approximately 200 kilometers north of [[Paris]]. It displays objects from the collections of the [[Musée du Louvre]] that are lent to the gallery on a medium- or long-term basis. The Louvre-Lens annex is part of an effort to provide access to French cultural institutions for people who live outside of Paris.{{cite web|title=Integrative Transparency: Louvre-Lens by SANAA and Tim Culbert |url=http://www.detail-online.com/architecture/news/integrative-transparency-louvre-lens-by-sanaa-020580.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114021348/http://www.detail-online.com/architecture/news/integrative-transparency-louvre-lens-by-sanaa-020580.html |archivedate=14 January 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2016}} Though the museum maintains close institutional links with the Louvre, it is primarily funded by the [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]] region.{{cite news|title= New Louvre museum in Lens, France, aims to revitalize mining town |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/11/AR2009121100124.html |work=The Washington Post |first=Angela |last=Doland |date=13 December 2009}} ==History== Because of criticism that French art and culture is limited to [[Paris]],{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-2243902/Louvre-opens-museum-branch-Lens-run-French-mining-town.html |location=London |work=Daily Mail |title=Art through a Lens: Louvre opens museum branch in run-down French mining town |date=6 December 2012}} the [[French Ministry of Culture|Ministry of Culture]] and the Louvre Directorate launched a plan, in 2003, to build a Louvre satellite museum in one of the 22 [[Regions of France]]. Only the [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais|Nord pas de Calais]] applied for the museum and proposed six cities: [[Lille]], [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais|Lens]], [[Valenciennes]], [[Calais]], [[Béthune]] and [[Boulogne-sur-Mer]]. In 2004, [[Jean-Pierre Raffarin]], then [[French Prime Minister]], announced Lens as the recipient city. The museum site was chosen in hopes of reversing the fortunes of the depressed Lens mining community, which was devastated by both [[World Wars]] and the [[Nazi occupation of France|Nazi occupation]], and suffered multiple mining catastrophes including the [[Courrières mine disaster]], the worst in European history, and a 1974 tragedy killing 42 miners.{{cite web|title=Louvre lands on a coal mine |url=http://museumzero.blogspot.com/2013/05/louvre-lands-on-coal-mine.html |author=Jonathan Price |date= 16 May 2013 |work=MuseumZero}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/12/28/archives/41-french-coal-miners-killed-by-explosion-and-fire.html |title=41 French Coal Miners Killed by Explosion and Fire |newspaper=The New York Times |date= 28 December 1974 | |accessdate=10 March 2017}} The last mine in Lens closed in 1986, which caused the unemployment rate to rise well above the French national average. "France abandoned us when the coal stopped, and we became a [[ghost town]]", said [[Pas-de-Calais]] president [[Daniel Percheron]].{{cite web|title=Louvre comes to poor French city, raising eyebrows |date=4 December 2012 |author=Thomas Adamson |work=Associated Press|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/louvre-comes-poor-french-city-raising-eyebrows}} Officials took inspiration from the economic transformation of the Spanish industrial municipality [[Bilbao]],{{cite web |title=The Bilbao Effect |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2002/09/the-bilbao-effect/302582/ |author=Witold Rybczynski |date=September 2002 |newspaper=The Atlantic}} which was caused, in part, by the construction of the [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] satellite (dubbed the [[Starchitect|"Bilbao effect"]], though some cautioned that the comparison is limited due to the much smaller population of Lens, and its lack of other tourist attractions.{{cite web|title=With the Louvre-Lens, a Curtain Call for the Bilbao Effect |url=http://www.theatlanticcities.com/arts-and-lifestyle/2012/12/louvre-lens-curtain-call-bilbao-effect/4161/ |date=14 December 2012 |author=Kriston Capps |work=City Lab, The Atlantic}}) Some Lens locals were critical of the project; they felt that the project to bring culture to their city was "patronizing". Other critics pointed out that the museum makes no attempt to address Lens's turbulent history or its current economic difficulties. A worldwide design contest was won by Japanese architectural firm [[SANAA]] in collaboration with New York firm Imrey Culbert, French [[landscape architect]] Catherine Mosbach, and [[Museology|museographer]] Studio Adrien Gardère.{{cite web|title=The Louvre-Lens Opens Today |url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/design/buildings/the-louvre-lens-opens-today_o |date=12 December 2012 |author=Deane Madsen |work=Architect Magazine}} The construction company [[Eiffage]] was chosen to construct the Lens-based Louvre branch, ultimately costing 150 million Euro (£121.6 million). The Louvre-Lens Museum, SANAA + Imrey Culbert's first building in France, was awarded the ''[[Prix de l'Équerre d'Argent|Prix d'architecture de l'Equerre d'Argent]]'' for 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.amc-archi.com/article/equerre-d-argent-2013-laureat-sanaa-le-louvre-lens,3|title=Équerre d'Argent 2013 / Lauréat - Sanaa - Le Louvre-Lens|last=Séron-Pierre|first=Catherine|date=11 February 2015|work=AMC Archi|access-date=10 March 2017|language=fr}} The French government hopes that the location near the northern border of France will be a draw for English, Belgian, and German tourists. In addition, the Louvre-Lens is near several World War [[memorials]], including the [[Canadian National Vimy Memorial]] in [[Vimy]],{{cite web|url=http://www.veterans.gc.ca/eng/memorials/france/vimy|title=Canadian National Vimy Memorial|work=Veterans Affairs Canada}} approximately 15 minutes from the Louvre-Lens. ==Museum== ===Architecture=== [[File :Le hall d'accueil du Louvre Lens (8540784674).jpg |thumb|alt=The reception hall with circular glass rooms|The reception hall]] The museum is built on a {{Convert|20|hectare|acre|lk=off|abbr=on|adj=on}} mining site that closed in the 1960s. The area is slightly elevated due to filling in of the mine.{{cite web|url=http://archiloci.com/louvre-lens-by-sanaa/|title=Diagram basis|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103132748/http://archiloci.com/louvre-lens-by-sanaa/|archivedate=3 November 2013}} To make the building blend into the surrounding area, the architects designed a string of five low-profile structures; the central one is square with glass walls and the others are rectangular with polished, aluminum facades that gave a blurry reflection of the surroundings.{{cite web|url=http://www.arcspace.com/features/sanaa/musee-louvre-lens/|title=Musée Louvre-Lens - SANAA|date=16 May 2013|newspaper=Arcspace.com|author=Eva Bjerring}} Altogether, the museum is {{Convert|360|m|ft|abbr=on}} long and contains {{Convert|28,000|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} of exhibition space. The design of a central building flanked by two wings mimics the Paris Louvre. The square, central building is the main reception area. It contains several curved glass rooms that contain a cafeteria, bookstore and museum boutique. To the east of the entry hall is the {{Convert|3,000|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} Galerie du Temps which houses approximately 200 items from the Paris Louvre collection. The items in the large, open hall are arranged chronologically, from 3,500 BC to the mid-19th century, regardless of style or country of origin. Beyond the Galerie du Temps is the Pavillon de Verre which exhibits works from neighboring museums.{{cite web|url=http://www.dezeen.com/2012/12/04/louvre-lens-by-sanaa-and-imrey-culbert/|title=Louvre Lens by SANAA and Imrey Culbert|date=4 December 2012|newspaper=Dezeen.com|accessdate=11 June 2016}} The building to the west of the entry hall is a gallery for temporary exhibits (the Exhibitions Temporaires) and, beyond that, an auditorium. [[File: La galerie du Temps (Louvre Lens) (8550665335).jpg |thumb|alt=visitors viewing the exhibits in the gallery|The Gallery du Temps]] === Temporary exhibits === The Exhibitions Temporaires is dedicated to exhibits which last 3 months. The first exhibition, titled ''Renaissance'', included Leonardo da Vinci's recently restored ''[[The Virgin and Child with St. Anne (Leonardo)|The Virgin and Child with St. Anne]].'' The second exhibit was dedicated to [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]] and included 170 of his works.{{cite web |url=http://www.louvrelens.fr/rubens-et-l-europe |title=Rubens et l'Europe - Louvre-Lens |archivedate=8 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308062524/http://www.louvrelens.fr/rubens-et-l-europe |accessdate=11 June 2016}} ==Inauguration, opening and visitors== On Dec 4, 2012, President [[François Hollande]], alongside first lady [[Valérie Trierweiler]], the Minister of Culture [[Aurélie Filippetti]], the director of Le Louvre [[Henri Loyrette]], the mayor of Lens [[Guy Delcourt (politician)|Guy Delcourt]], and former prime ministers [[Lionel Jospin]] and [[Pierre Mauroy]] officially opened the Louvre-Lens.{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/fr/20121204-lens-musee-louvre-culture-nord-pas-de-calais-inauguration-francois-hollande |title=Lens inaugure son musée du Louvre |date=4 December 2012 |work=France24 }} The following weekend, the museum welcomed its first visitors; three weeks after the opening, the museum welcomed its 100,000th visitor. In May 2013, during [[Long Night of Museums|Long Night of Museums 2013]], 500,000 visitors viewed the masterpieces displayed in the Louvre-Lens Museum.{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2012/12/28/succes-pour-le-louvre-lens-trois-semaines-apres-son-inauguration_1811241_3246.html |title=Succès pour le Louvre-Lens, trois semaines après son inauguration |newspaper=Lemonde.fr |date=28 Dec 2012 |author= |accessdate= 11 June 2016}} While {{formatnum:700000}} visitors were anticipated for the first year (while admission was free), the year's final tally was approximately {{formatnum:900000}}.{{Cite web |url= http://nord-pas-de-calais.france3.fr/2013/12/01/le-louvre-lens-un-deja-900000-visiteurs-367375.html |title= Le Louvre-Lens a un an : déjà 900 000 visiteurs |publisher= ''[[France 3 Nord-Pas-de-Calais]]'' |author= [[Agence France-Presse]], E.M. |accessdate= 1 December 2013 }} On Feb 7 2013, a woman vandalized a major masterpiece of the museum, [[Liberty guiding the people|''Liberty Guiding the People'']], writing "AE911" on it with a black marker, possibly a reference to a group calling itself "Architects & Engineers for 9/11 Truth".{{cite web |url=http://en.rfi.fr/culture/20130208-woman-scrawls-911-graffiti-over-delacroix-masterpiece-Louvre |title=Woman scrawls 9/11 graffiti over Delacroix masterpiece in Louvre-Lens |newspaper=En.rfi.fr |date=8 February 2013 |author= |accessdate=11 June 2016}} The painting has been fully restored. == Gallery == File:Royal portrait - Hamurabi - King of Babylon -1900 before JC -.JPG|A royal head thought to represent [[Hammurabi]], King of [[Babylon]] (ca. 2000 BC){{cite web |url=http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/royal-head-known-head-hammurabi |title=Royal head, known as the "Head of Hammurabi" |newspaper=Louvre.fr |author=Iselin Claire |accessdate= June 11, 2016}} File:Raqqa - Syrie - Fragment frise architecturale.JPG| A fragment of an architectural frieze from [[Raqqa]] with a Koranic inscription in angular Arabic (1100-1200) File:Menphis - Egypte - 500before JC - Troop of funerary servant figures shabtis in the name of Neferibreheb.JPG|A group of [[ushabti]] from the tomb of Neferibreheb in [[Memphis, Egypt]] (ca. 500 BC) File:Mithra sacrifiant le Taureau-005.JPG|[[Mithra]] sacrificing the bull (ca. 100–200 AD) File:Théodose II - italie vers 440.JPG|A prince of the family of the Emperor of the East, [[Theodosius II]] (Italy, ca. 440 AD) File:Parthenay vers 1150-1200 - Notre Dame de la Couldre - Bustes de Rois de France.JPG|Busts of kings of France from Notre Dame de la Couldre in [[Parthenay]], France (ca. 1150–1200) File:Chaumont-en-Bassigny.JPG|A fragment of a chapel of the Saint-Sepulcre in [[Chaumont, Haute-Marne|Chaumont-en-Bassigny]] (1475) File:Carlo_Crivelli_St_James_of_the_Marches_1477.jpg|''[[James of the Marches]]'' by [[Carlo Crivelli]] (1477) File:Baldassare Castiglione de Raphael.JPG|''[[Portrait of Baldassare Castiglione]]'' by [[Raphael]] (ca. 1514–1515) File:Giambologna -1620 1529-1610 Deianira.JPG|''The Abduction of [[Deianira]]'' by [[Giambologna]] (ca. 1576){{cite web |url=http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/abduction-deianira |title=The Abduction of Deianira |newspaper=Louvre.fr |date= |author=Baratte Sophie |accessdate= June 11, 2016}} File:Rembrandt 1661 1606-1669 Saint-Matthieu.JPG|''Saint Matthew'' by [[Rembrandt]] (1661) File:Hyacinthe Rigaud 1685 Jules-Hardouin Mansart-001.JPG|''[[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]]'' by [[Hyacinthe Rigaud]] (1685) File:Bertel Thorvaldsen - Venus with Apple.JPG|''Venus with Apple'' by [[Bertel Thorvaldsen]] (1805). File:Antoine-Louis Barye-001.JPG|''[[Lion with a Snake]]'' by [[Antoine-Louis Barye]] (1832, cast by Honoré Gonon in 1835) File:Ferdinand-Philippe 1810-1842 by Jean-louis Jaley 1802-1866.JPG|''[[Prince Ferdinand Philippe, Duke of Orléans]]'' by [[Jean-Louis Jaley]] (1844) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Louvre-Lens}} * [http://www.louvrelens.fr/en/ Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080726064352/http://www.specifier.com.au/projects/museums/31569/Art-On-The-March-The-Louvre-Lens-and-The-Pompidou-Metz.html Images and profile at ''Specifier Magazine''] * [http://www.gonomad.com/5161 Travel article about the museum] {{Louvre}} {{Portal bar|France|Arts}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Lens, Pas-de-Calais]] [[Category:Louvre]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in France]] [[Category:Museums in Pas-de-Calais]] [[Category:2012 establishments in France]] [[Category:Art museums established in 2012]] [[Category:SANAA buildings]]

revision.text:
'''M13486''' ('''MIL-C-13486''' or '''MIL-DTL-13486''') is a frequently used [[United States Military Standard|MIL-SPEC]] wire and a heavy duty vehicle and aircraft electrical cable.
The MIL-DTL-13486 military specification was last revised in May 2006 and was originally created by the Department of Defense. The specification typically covers special purpose electrical cables that are heavy-duty for low-tension circuits. The wire may have either one or two conductors and be either shielded or unshielded.
M13486 wire has gained popularity in recent years due to its widespread use for all types of military ground vehicles, including tanks, trailers, trucks, and jeeps. The wire is also used in exposed situations due to its resistance to abrasion, fluids, and weather. Additionally, the MIL-Spec wire is recognized for possessing superior flexibility at most temperatures. M13486 is usually fungus resistant. The wire is typically constructed with a stranded tinned copper conductor, rubber insulating core, inner glass braid and a jacket.
Popular specifications for M13486 wire include M13486/1, M13486/12, and M13486/14. M13486 wire may be on a designated Qualified Products List.
== See also == * [[Defense Standard]] * [[Electrical wiring]] * [[10603]]
== References == * 1. "MIL-Spec Wire Types." [https://web.archive.org/web/20080929155826/http://www.militarywire.org/typesofmil-specwire.htm] * 2. "Index of DSCC MIL Specs & Drawings." Defense Supply Center Columbus. [http://www.dscc.dla.mil/Programs/MilSpec/].
[[Category:Military of the United States standards]] [[Category:Standards]] [[Category:Electrical wiring]]

{{Infobox NRHP | name =Nathan Hale Homestead | image = Nathan Hale Homestead.JPG | caption = | location = [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]], [[Connecticut]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41.7651|-72.3464|display=title,inline}} | area = | built = 1777 | architect = | architecture = | added = October 22, 1970 | refnum = 70000698 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [http://www.ctlandmarks.org Connecticut Landmarks] }} The '''Nathan Hale Homestead''' is a historic home located at 2299 South Street in [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]], [[Connecticut]]. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1970, and was also known as '''Deacon Richard Hale House'''.
[[Connecticut Landmarks]] operates the house a late 18th-century [[historic house museum]], however, they are currently facing an investigation by the attorney general's office into their alleged neglect of the Homestead and its artifacts.<ref>https://www.theday.com/local-columns/20180303/ex-landmarks-employee-nathan-hale-bible-left-to-rot-in-closet</ref><ref>https://www.theday.com/local-columns/20180308/connecticuts-mona-lisa-sits-inside-shuttered-landmarks-house</ref>
==Nathan Hale== [[File:Nathan-hale-cityhall.jpg|left|thumb|150px|A statue of Nathan Hale in City Hall Park, New York]] {{Main|Nathan Hale}}
Nathan Hale was a spy for the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. A graduate of [[Yale]], he taught school for two years, first in [[East Haddam, Connecticut|East Haddam]], then in [[New London, Connecticut|New London]].
After being captured by the [[Great Britain|British]], Hale reportedly gave a speech stating that his only regret was that he had but one life to give for his country.{{sfn|Seymour| p=xxv}}
After he was hanged, his body was not returned and was never found. There is a monument to him in a cemetery in his hometown of Coventry, Connecticut.
Nathan Hale is Connecticut's state hero.<ref>[http://www.ctlandmarks.org/hale.php Nathan Hale on Connecticut Landmarks website]</ref>
==The House== Despite the name of the property, Nathan Hale never lived in the house that is named for him. As a child, he did live in a home that was located in the same spot. This house was razed by his parents in order to create a larger living space for the family.
News of Nathan's death came when his family grew concerned for his well-being. His brother traveled from Coventry to [[Old Saybrook, Connecticut|Old Saybrook]] to meet with the army and inquire about Nathan's whereabouts. He was informed that Nathan had been killed and was given a trunk of his belongings. This trunk is in the house.
[[File:NATHAN HALE HOMESTEAD, COVENTRY,, TOLLAND COUNTY, CT..jpg|thumb|Interior of the house]] After the Hale family, the house was sold to a series of other families who used it as a private residence, and the story of Nathan Hale became forgotten as just another story of a fallen soldier. However, a Connecticut lawyer named [[George Dudley Seymour]] became fascinated by the story while living in New Haven and was instrumental in the effort to recognize Hale's efforts. After championing the cause of erecting a statue of Nathan Hale at Yale University, Seymour learned that the farm in Coventry, which had been owned by Nathan's father, the Reverend Deacon Richard Hale, was for sale and in disrepair. He purchased the property in 1914 and restored the house to its original dignity, furnishing it with Connecticut antiques and artifacts, including Nathan's trunk.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.s560.com/dokuwiki/book:george_dudley_seymour George Dudley Seymour article from Seymour Wiki Genealogy site]</ref>
In addition, he purchased the property across the street. Named the [[Strong-Porter House]], it was the home of Nathan's grandmother, and is also a museum and on the list of National Registered Historic Places.
In a further effort to recognize Nathan Hale's sacrifice, Seymour also convinced the federal government to print a Nathan Hale postage stamp in 1925.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> The stamp was designed by artist [[Bela Lyon Pratt]], who also created the statue of Nathan at [[Fort Nathan Hale]] in New Haven.
==Possible Hauntings== Seymour was of the belief that the homestead was haunted. According to a diary entry, he and a friend reportedly viewed the spirit of Reverend Deacon Hale through a window one rainy night. Also believed to be in residence is the spirit of Lydia Carpenter, a servant of the Hale family, and of Joseph Hale, Nathan's brother.
Mary Elizabeth Campbell Griffith, the widow of a former caretaker of the homestead, believed that the house might have been haunted by John and Sarah Hale, Nathan's brother and sister-in-law.<ref name="NormanScott2002">{{cite book|author1=Michael Norman|author2=Beth Scott|title=Haunted heritage|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hb8r2obx1lAC&pg=PA23|accessdate=17 October 2010|date=18 October 2002|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-7653-0173-4|pages=22–25}}</ref>
==The Property== [[File:Nathan Hale Homestead stone marker.JPG|thumb|140px|Stone marker explaining Holy Grove]] Surrounding the house is the [[Nathan Hale State Forest]], maintained by the [[Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection]].
Next to the house is a corn field that is planted every year. In October, friends of the Hale Homestead put on a haunted corn maze.
In front of the homestead is a triangular grassy plot of land containing maple trees planted by Nathan's nephew David Hale Junior in 1812. The area has come to be known as the Holy Grove, in part because neighbors used to hold prayer meetings there.{{sfn|Seymour| p=487}}
==See also== {{Portal|Connecticut}} *[[Captain Nathan Hale Monument]], also NRHP-listed *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Tolland County, Connecticut]] *Connecticut Landmarks also operates other [[historic house museums]], including: ** [[Bellamy-Ferriday House and Garden]] in [[Bethlehem, Connecticut|Bethlehem]] ** [[Butler-McCook Homestead|Butler-McCook House & Garden]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] ** [[Buttolph-Williams House]] in [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]] ** [[Joshua Hempsted House|Hempsted Houses]] in [[New London, Connecticut|New London]] ** [[Isham-Terry House]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] ** [[Phelps-Hatheway House & Garden]] in [[Suffield, Connecticut|Suffield]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * {{cite book|author=George D. Seymour|title=Documentary Life of Nathan Hale: Comprising All Available Official and Private Documents Bearing on the Life of the Patriot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PxkkjSRgMiAC&pg=PA487|accessdate=17 October 2010|date=May 2006|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-1-4286-0043-0| ref=harv}}
==External links== * [http://www.ctlandmarks.org/ Official site]
{{National Register of Historic Places}} {{Connecticut}}
